title: Dienstmann
text:
A Dienstmann (plural: "Dienstleute" or, in Austria, "Dienstmänner") was a <a href="medieval%20retainer">medieval retainer</a> or <a href="vassal">vassal</a> and, later, a hired man, in German-speaking countries, particularly in <a href="Austria">Austria</a> until the first half of the 20th century.
Usage.
The term "Dienstmann" first surfaced in the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a> as a Germanicization of the Latin word <a href="ministerialis">ministerialis</a>, for men, who served at a court and, in the course of time, were raised to be <a href="armiger">armiger</a>s with a social status similar to that of free <a href="knight">knight</a>s ("Ritter").
However the term "Dienstmann" could also refer to men who were obliged to pay duties or render <a href="socage">socage</a> to their <a href="liege%20lord">liege lord</a>s a "<a href="socager">socager</a>", or "socman". Unlike <a href="ministeriales">ministeriales</a>, they held a lower social rank equivalent to the English <a href="serf">serf</a>.
Later, the term described was used to describe a hired man who, in public service or in a private household, was contracted to perform time-limited functions of all types in return for a fee. His main duties were the carriage of belongings, such as <a href="suitcase">suitcase</a>s, and messenger duties.
In fiction.
Well-known fictional "Dienstmänner" are the "Dienstmann", Alois Hingerl, in <a href="Ludwig%20Thoma">Ludwig Thoma</a>'s Satire "Ein Münchner im Himmel" or <a href="Hans%20Moser%20%28actor%29">Hans Moser</a> and <a href="Paul%20H%C3%B6rbiger">Paul Hörbiger</a>, the "Dienstmänner" in the film "Hallo Dienstmann". As a so-called "Berliner Original", the "Dienstmann", Ferdinand Strumpf, went under the name, Eckensteher Nante.
